144.heading: Doragon Ai. English.
144.title: Dragon Eye
144.author: Kairi Fujiyama ; translated and adapted by Mari Morimoto ; lettered by North Market Street Graphics.
notes: "First published in Japan in 2005 by Kodansha, Ltd., Tokyo"

Summary (from OCLC): Ten years after a virus began turning victims into monsters called Dracules, Leila Mikami is a member of the elite VIUS squad, who stand between what remains of civilization and chaos. Leila has an agenda, however; a Dracule killed both her parents and she seeks the Dragon Eye, a magic weapon that will make her the most powerful warrior in the world, in order to exact revenge.

231.heading: DorÃ©, Gustave, 1832-1883--Miscellanea.
231.title: "La BD sur le Terrain"
231.author: Vincent BerniÃ¨re
231.appears_in: p. 46-55 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du MusÃ©e de la Bande DessinÃ©e, no. 7 (Jan. 2002).
notes: Begins: "Tintin, reporter au 'Petit VingtiÃ¨me', Fantasio, envoyÃ© spÃ©cial du 'Moustique', Ric Hochet, journaliste Ã  'La Rafale', Jeannette Pointu, reporter photographe, Clark Kent alias Superman, journaliste du 'Daily Planet'. Avec tous ces personnages fictifs, parmi les plus illustres, ayant embrassÃ© la carriÃ¨re de journaliste, il Ã©tait dit qu'un jour ou l'autre, la bande dessinÃ©e se prÃ©ocuperait plus particuliÃ¨rement de reportages."

English summary (from p. 150): "Comic Art in the Field. As a genre, comic art for reporting is difficult to define. Today however, it clearly represents a rapidly developing trend. Vincent BerniÃ¨re draws up a genealogy of this testimonial or, more rarely, investigative comic art. He looks at the satirical prints of Gillray, studies courtroom sketches, and examines reports by Gustave DorÃ©, Steinberg, Eisner, Silverstein and Crumb. He then proceeds to draw up the inventory of the many attempts at this genre published over the past few years."
